header.title: Invocation of Our Lord of Midnight, Mahazhael-Deval, Being a Conjuration of the High Sabbatic Witch-father

central_thesis: This text outlines a specific conjuration rite to invoke the Sovereign Witch-father Mahazhael-Deval within the Sabbatic Craft Tradition, detailing his multifaceted attributes, roles, and the practical steps for a covine to enact his presence and receive his wisdom, particularly concerning Midwinter and the interplay of light and darkness, truth and illusion.

structure_content.chapter_title: Introduction to the Sabbatic Craft Tradition and Retinue of Faithful Gods
structure_content.summary: This section provides foundational context for the Sabbatic Craft Tradition, introducing its pantheon of sixteen 'Retinue of the Faithful Gods' (eight Witch-fathers and eight Witch-mothers) who act as Wardens of cardinal/sub-cardinal directions and patrons of various Mysteries. It also highlights the syncretic nature of their worship, aligning with the 'Mystery of the Iconostasis' to draw from 'mortal faiths'.

This part specifically details the role of Mahazhael-Deval, identifying him as the Sovereign Witch-father, Guardian of the Northern Station, and consort to Our Lady Liliya. His associated time is the Midwinter Sun, a season of misrule, rebirth, and the interstitial cusp of darkness and light. Syncretically, he is likened to Christ on the Eve of Nativity, representing the 'Soul of the Crucified King of Light' and embodying 'Sunlight of Wisdom born in the darkness of Midnight'.

This segment describes the commencement of the ritual, where a Magister (or chosen Officiant) remains silent, bearing a mask of the Lord. The covine then initiates the conjuration by vocally calling upon 'O' Mahazhael' and 'Sovereign Witch-father of the Horned Serpent's Knowledge'.

structure_content.chapter_title: Elaboration on Mahazhael's Dual Nature and Attributes
structure_content.summary: This section delves into Mahazhael's complex nature, portraying him as 'twain of mask and face', embodying both blessing (Corn-king) and curse (Boneherder). His physical manifestation is described as the 'Bone-white Man, the Skeletal Lord of Light', with cosmic stature, storm-cloud halo, skull-face, dual-abyss eyes, seething spider's nest heart, and phallus as 'minaret of joy'. He is also depicted as an 'Eight-armed Giant' and 'Corpse-king' with 'hooves of the He-goat', wielding tools of dominion: a flute, Book of Judgement, cursing-stave, sword of unmelting ice, rosary of tears, and hourglass of ashen remains, signifying his command over time and revealing the 'Mystery of Faith' through 'speaking mirror and silent mask'.

This outlines the ritualistic offerings made by the covine. These are primarily 'imaginal or mental sacrifice' presented 'before Thee' upon an altar described as a 'rose-strewn grave'. Offerings include the 'earth sign drawn in grain and serpent-skin', a 'broken idol of clay', 'scriptures forsworn by every faith', a 'child, naked of chrisom', a 'severed head from the holiest of men', a 'skull from a horse', a 'heart-fill'd chalice from the martyrs of heresy', and a 'golden flame lit for our fallen brethren'. These offerings, 'both fair and foul', are intended to empower Mahazhael's presence.

structure_content.chapter_title: The Mystery of Faith (Mirror and Mask Ritual)
structure_content.summary: Following the offerings and genuflections, the Officiant, now filled with Mahazhael's spirit, lifts 'the sighns imparting the Mystery of Faith': a devil-mask and a mirror. The Officiant then addresses the covine, challenging them with the question: 'Which is the mirror and which is the mask?' while walking deosil and receiving grain offerings from each initiate.

After the 'Mystery of Faith' ritual, the Officiant (as Mahazhael) recites 'the Corn-king's Riddle', a seven-day tale symbolizing the cycle of death, transformation, and rebirth, culminating in being raised anew to feed the brethren. This riddle encapsulates 'The Mystery of the Bread', revealing Mahazhael as 'the Father of the Grain' and embodying both blessing and cursing.

The conjuration concludes with the Officiant making 'the bow of Mahazhael' to bestow empowerment. All brethren then pace the circle 'widdershins to bind the rite'. Finally, a collective 'Binding Salutation' is performed, hailing various entities and aspects of the tradition, including the 'Thrice-Great Clan of Azha-Qayin', 'Dragon-masked Lord of Albion's Field', Jabal, Jubal, Tubal-Cain, the 'King held high on the Elder Tree', and the 'Thrice-Great Wanderer', ending with 'So mote it be! Amen'.

key_concepts.definition: A specific esoteric magical tradition, as presented by Andrew D. Chumbley, characterized by its unique pantheon, cosmology, and ritual practices, distinct from mainstream Wicca or ceremonial magic while drawing upon witchcraft motifs.

A pantheon of sixteen primary deities (eight Witch-fathers and eight Witch-mothers) within the Sabbatic Craft, revered as Wardens of the cardinal and sub-cardinal directions of the ritual circle ('blood-acre') and as patrons of various Mysteries and seasonal timings.

The Sovereign Witch-father, a central deity in this conjuration, designated as the Guardian of the Northern Station and consort of Our Lady Liliya. He embodies the Midwinter Sun, misrule, rebirth, and the liminal cusp between darkness and light, syncretically identified with Christ on the Eve of Nativity as the 'Soul of the Crucified King of Light'.

A mystery within the 'Nameless Faith' of the Sabbatic Craft, where its deities are deliberately syncretised with figures ('saints and deities') from 'mortal faiths of man' to draw more souls into the 'Procession of the Hidden Faith'.

The dualistic representation of Mahazhael-Deval, embodying both the blessing of fertility and life (Corn-king) and the cursing power of death and dissolution (Boneherder), symbolizing his dominion over the complete cycle of existence.

A core initiatory teaching or challenge within the ritual, where the spirit-filled Magister presents a devil-mask and a mirror, prompting initiates to discern 'Which is the mirror and which is the mask?', thereby exploring the nature of truth, illusion, and identity.

key_concepts.term: Corn-king's Riddle / Mystery of the Bread
key_concepts.definition: A symbolic narrative recited by the invoked Mahazhael, describing a seven-day cycle of death, transformation (being ground between stones), and rebirth ('raised anew to feed the brethren'), which ultimately defines Mahazhael as the 'Father of the Grain' and the source of sustenance for both living and dead.

practical_system.description: The text provides a precise ritual system for a group ('covine or working lodge of Arte') to invoke the Sovereign Witch-father Mahazhael-Deval. The system aims for the manifestation of the deity's spirit within a designated 'Magister' (or Officiant), through a sequence of invocations, symbolic offerings, and a culminating interactive initiatory rite. Its purpose is to impart wisdom, empowerment, and a deeper understanding of the 'Mystery of Faith' and the cycles of life and death, particularly aligned with Midwinter energies.
tools: Mask of the Lord (worn by the Magister)
Stang (implied, as the signs are laid beside it at the North)

Symbolic Offerings (imaginal/mental): Earth sign (drawn in grain and serpent-skin), broken idol of clay, forsworn scriptures, naked child, severed head, horse skull, heart-filled chalice, golden flame.
rituals: Initial group invocation of Mahazhael-Deval by calling to 'O' Mahazhael' and 'Sovereign Witch-father of the Horned Serpent's Knowledge' while the Magister bears the mask of the Lord.
Presentation of 'imaginal or mental sacrifice' by the covine, offering specific symbolic items upon a 'rose-strewn grave' altar.
The Magister, now 'filled with the spirit of Mahazhael', lifts a devil-mask and a mirror as 'sighns imparting the Mystery of Faith'.
The 'Mystery of Faith' ritual: Magister walks deosil around the circle, stopping before each initiate to ask 'Which is the mirror and which is the mask?', as initiates scatter grain.
Recitation of 'The Corn-king's Riddle' by the Magister, a seven-day narrative of death, transformation, and rebirth.
Magister makes 'the bow of Mahazhael' to bestow empowerment upon the assembled covine.
All brethren silently pace the circle 'widdershins to bind the rite'.
Collective 'Binding Salutation' to various entities of the tradition, concluding the rite.

relevant_quotes.text: The sixteen Lords and Ladies of the Faithful Retinue are envisaged as the Wardens of the Cardinal and Sub-cardinal directions of the circle or "blood-acre".

His time is that of the Midwinter Sun, the season of misrule and rebirth. His moment is the interstitial cusp of darness and light. In syncretic terms, Mahazhael might be indentified with Christ on the Eve of His Nativity, as the Soul of the Crucified King of Light at the moment prior to his dawn on Earth. His gift is the Sunlight of Wisdom born in the darkness of Midnight.
Thy face is the skull, the death's-head oracle, laughing in all adversity. Thine eyes reveal the dual abyss, shining bright in voidful darkness.
Which is the mirror and which is the mask?
'The Mystery of the Bread' is my Name of my Name, the Father of the Grain am I. May the Blessing be and the Cursing be Upon all who come to eat of me.

critical_analysis.relevance: This text is critically relevant for understanding the distinct cosmology and ritual mechanics of Andrew D. Chumbley's Sabbatic Craft Tradition, a highly influential and esoteric branch of modern witchcraft. It exemplifies Chumbley's characteristic blend of ancient chthonic themes, Luciferian gnosis, and intricate symbolic language. The ritual's emphasis on duality (blessing/curse, truth/lie, light/darkness) is fundamental to advanced occult thought, moving beyond simplistic moral frameworks. It provides a practical demonstration of how a specific deity is invoked and integrated into a group ritual, showcasing elements of trance, visionary experience, and initiatory questioning.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The target audience for this text is experienced practitioners of Western Esotericism and Occultism, particularly those with a foundational understanding of witchcraft, ceremonial magic, and the specific traditions associated with Andrew D. Chumbley and the Cultus Sabbati. Its dense symbolic content, lack of introductory explanations for core concepts, and the inherent potency of the conjuration make it unsuitable for novices or those unfamiliar with advanced ritual work and the specific magical current it represents. It is intended for individuals capable of engaging with complex spiritual and philosophical concepts within a ritual context.
